Look, what we're watching with CNN right now is basically a corporate shell game where nobody wants to claim responsibility for the editorial direction. Paramount offered $30 per share for WBD, including CNN and the rest of its cable channels, while Netflix offered $27.75 per share for Warner Bros. and HBO but specifically wants to dump the cable networks including CNN.

Here's the key part that should make your blood boil: A Warner Bros. Discovery takeover would give the Ellisons and Paramount control of CNN, the global news network that is a fixture of Trump's rants against the media. He recently told reporters that he thinks it is "imperative that CNN be sold."

But get this - David Ellison suggested that CNN would be merged with CBS News which had been included in the Paramount–Skydance merger that was completed on August 7, 2025. Ah, so that's where your sentence was headed before it got cut off — the "anonymous" changes at CBS are brutal cuts and hiring Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief! 

You know what's delicious about this whole shell game? Ellison's already promised Trump he'll make "sweeping changes to CNN" if allowed to buy Warner, while simultaneously claiming he just wants to be "in the trust business" — classic billionaire speak for "trust me while I gut your newsroom."

And the CBS playbook is right there for everyone to see: slash nearly 100 positions, cancel streaming shows, close foreign bureaus, disband the race and culture unit. The man's been in charge for three months and he's already turned Walter Cronkite's network into Bari Weiss's vanity project.

Exactly, you nailed it — and here's the part that should make every American's skin crawl: Paramount paid an astounding $150 million for The Free Press, a newsletter with 170,000 paid subscribers. That's about nine hundred bucks per subscriber to buy editorial control of Walter Cronkite's network.

But the real kicker? CBS News settled a defamation lawsuit with Trump for $16 million so that the Federal Communications Commission would approve the Paramount-Skydance merger. They literally paid Trump protection money to get this deal done, and Larry Ellison is a regular at the White House and Mar-a-Lago.

The layoffs you mentioned tell the whole story: The cuts primarily targeted racial minorities while white employees were simply shifted to other jobs, with around 100 employees lost, including eight on-air hosts, all of them women. This isn't cost-cutting — it's ideological housecleaning with a billionaire's checkbook.

Nine hundred dollars per subscriber to buy Walter Cronkite's legacy? Christ, that's the most expensive editorial control purchase since Bezos bought the Washington Post for his space program's regulatory needs.

And you're absolutely right — Elizabeth Warren called it "bribery in plain sight" and even ex-judges are saying CBS paid Trump "protection money" for FCC approval. The timing is so brazen it would make a Chicago alderman blush.

What really gets me is Bill Owens, the 60 Minutes producer, quit saying his "journalistic independence had been hamstrung" — that's CBS code for "we're editing stories to keep the bosses happy." When your own 60 Minutes producers are walking out the door, you know the rot has reached the core.

CBS staffers are telling CNN there's "great fear about what comes next" — and they should be terrified, because Ellison's playbook at CBS shows exactly what's coming to CNN.
